speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when you first started noticing these feeding difficulties and abdominal distension? Was it sudden or did it start gradually?

speaker: Patient
text: I think it started a few days ago, and it's been getting worse. I was feeding okay, but then I just started feeling really uncomfortable and fussy, and now I don't want to eat at all.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the fussiness and discomfort you're experiencing? Is it constant or does it come and go, and is there anything that seems to make it better or worse?

speaker: Patient
text: It's like... I get really upset when my tummy is pressed or touched, and it feels hard and tight. Sometimes I cry a lot, and it gets really loud. When my mom tries to hold me or change my diaper, I just don't like it and I fuss a lot.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me the position of your abdomen right now, please? I'd like to examine it further.

speaker: Patient
text: *winces slightly as the doctor presses on my abdomen* Ow... it feels really uncomfortable. *fidgets and squirms slightly*

speaker: Doctor
text:
I can see that you're experiencing some significant discomfort, and I want to make sure I understand what's going on. Can you tell me, is there anything that you've noticed that might be related to the discomfort, like a fever, vomiting, or blood in your stool?

And can you show me the position of your abdomen again, and I'll take a closer look?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't know, it just feels like my tummy hurts all the time. And when my mom holds me, it feels tight and squishy, like there's something inside me that's moving around. I try to squirm away, but it just gets worse.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the positioning of your abdomen when you feel the discomfort, is it more to one side or does it feel like it's all over?

Also, when you say it feels tight and squishy, can you describe the sensation to me, is it more like gas, or does it feel like there's something solid inside?

Can you show me your abdomen again and I'll gently press on it to see if I can feel anything else?

speaker: Patient
text:
*whimper* It's all over, it feels like it's all over my tummy. *tries to squirm away, then stills down slightly* When I'm on my back, it feels a bit worse, but when I'm on my side, it's not as bad. *looks down, fidgeting slightly*

It's hard to explain, but it's like... when I'm lying down, I feel like there's a big bubble in my tummy. It feels like it's moving around and it makes me feel uncomfortable. *lifts head up slightly, eyes fixed on the doctor* *tries to cross legs, showing a slight separation between thighs*

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the separation between your thighs when you try to cross them, is it a noticeable gap or is it just a slight feeling of looseness?

Also, when you're lying down, does the sensation of the "bubble" in your tummy seem to change when you move your legs or change positions?

And can you point to the exact spot on your abdomen where you feel the discomfort the most?

speaker: Patient
text:
*crosses legs slightly more, trying to show the gap between the thighs* It's a bit of a gap, but it's not too big, just a little bit. *looks down at the gap, fidgeting slightly*

When I move my legs, it doesn't seem to change the feeling inside, but when I turn around or change positions, it feels a bit worse. *frowns slightly*

*points to the middle of my abdomen, near my belly button* It hurts the most right here. *tenses up slightly, trying to show the exact spot*

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'm going to request a test to take a closer look at your abdomen. REQUEST TEST: Abdominal Ultrasound. 

Also, I'd like to do a quick examination of your abdomen to see if I can feel anything else. 

Can you show me the position of your mouth, is it open or closed?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Abdominal Ultrasound: Dilated bowel segments with absence of gas in the rectum, suggesting a possible obstruction; Abdominal Examination: Abdomen is soft but distended, with crying intensifying on palpation especially in the left lower quadrant, a tympanitic sound noted in the left lower quadrant, and a visible gap between the thighs, approximately 1 cm in diameter; Vital Signs: Temperature: 36.8°C (98.2°F), Blood Pressure: Normal for age, Heart Rate: 120 bpm (normal for age), Respiratory Rate: 30 breaths/min (normal for age).

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'd like to ask a few more questions to confirm the findings from the ultrasound and examination. Can you tell me, is there a history of any recent illnesses or infections that might be contributing to this condition?

Also, can you show me where the tympanitic sound is located, is it more to the left or to the right of the belly button?

Can you try to move your leg to see if it makes the discomfort worse or better?

REQUEST TEST: Blood work to check for any signs of infection or inflammation.

*listens to the heartbeat and breathing, making a note*

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Blood work: WBC: 10.5 x 10^9/L (slightly elevated, may indicate mild inflammation), Hemoglobin: 13.5 g/dL (slightly below normal), Platelets: 150 x 10^9/L (slightly below normal).

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the timing of the vomiting, if you've been vomiting at all, and if so, how often and what's the consistency of the vomit?

Also, can you point to the exact spot where you feel the tympanitic sound, and can you describe it to me, is it more of a crunching sound or a hollow sound?

And I'd like to request another test to take a closer look at your bowel movements. REQUEST TEST: Stool exam. 

Also, can you show me your face and let me examine your mouth and oral cavity to see if there are any signs of oral thrush or other issues that might be contributing to your discomfort.

And one more thing, can you tell me, how would you describe the crying when you're in pain, is it more of a high-pitched cry or a low-pitched cry?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Blood work: WBC: 10.5 x 10^9/L (slightly elevated, may indicate mild inflammation), Hemoglobin: 13.5 g/dL (slightly below normal), Platelets: 150 x 10^9/L (slightly below normal).

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've reviewed the test results, and I'd like to ask a few more questions to confirm the findings. Can you tell me, have you noticed any blood in your stool or black, tarry stools?

Also, can you show me the position of your mouth when you're not eating or feeding, is it open or closed?

And I'd like to request another test to take a closer look at your bowel movements. REQUEST TEST: Stool exam.

I'd also like to examine your anal area to see if there are any signs of irritation or infection. Can you show me the position of your anus, and I'll gently examine it.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've reviewed the test results and the patient's response, and I'd like to ask a few more questions to confirm the findings. Can you tell me, how long have you been experiencing this discomfort and abdominal distension, and have you noticed any changes in your appetite or stool consistency?

Also, I'd like to examine your perineal area to see if there are any signs of irritation or infection. Can you show me the position of your perineum, and I'll gently examine it?

Is there anything else you can tell me about your symptoms, such as fever, vomiting, or changes in urination?

And one more thing, can you show me the position of your legs when you're not crossing them, is it straight or slightly bent?

speaker: Patient
text:
I don't know, I just wake up feeling like this. I don't remember it being different before. My mom says I've been eating okay, but I don't want to eat as much as I used to. And I've been having trouble going to the bathroom, it feels like there's something stuck.

It feels like it's getting worse when my mom holds me or changes my diaper, but it's hard to explain. When I'm on my side, it's not as bad, but when I'm on my back, it feels worse. 

I don't know, it's hard to describe. It just feels like there's something inside me that's moving around and making me uncomfortable. 

*crosses legs more, trying to show the gap between the thighs* It's a bit bigger when I'm on my back, but it's still just a little bit. 

I don't think it changes when I move my legs, but it gets worse when I turn around or change positions. *frowns slightly* 

*points to the middle of my abdomen, near my belly button* It hurts the most right here.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me, have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, vomiting, or changes in urination? 

And one more thing, I'd like to review your overall development, are you having any trouble with bowel movements, such as constipation or diarrhea, and have you had any issues with urination, like painful urination or difficulty starting to urinate?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't feel like I have a fever, I just feel really uncomfortable and fussy all the time. I don't really like it when my mom holds me or changes my diaper, it makes me cry a lot. And I don't want to eat much because it hurts when I try to drink from my bottle.

text:

Also, I'd like to request another test to take a closer look at your bowel movements. REQUEST TEST: Fecal occult blood test.

I'm going to take a closer look at your perineal area... (examination) Hmm, I do see some mild erythema and irritation in the anal area, which suggests that there might be some infection or inflammation present. I'm also going to check your stool again to see if there's any blood present.

Can you tell me more about your bowel movements? Are you having any trouble passing stool, or is it just that you don't want to eat much because of the discomfort?

speaker: Patient
text: *looks up at the doctor with tears in eyes* I don't see anything... *points to the rectal area, but doesn't see anything*

speaker: Doctor
text:
I can see that you're really scared and uncomfortable. I want to reassure you that we're going to do everything we can to help you feel better. Can you tell me more about what happens when you see your mom or dad holding you or changing your diaper? Do you feel like it's the same thing that's causing you discomfort? 

Can you point to the spot on your abdomen where it hurts the most? I want to take a closer look.

text: *sniffles* I don't like it when they hold me or change my diaper. It feels like... it feels like something is moving around inside me. *looks down at the gap between the thighs* It's like there's a big bubble in my tummy. *tries to cross legs again, showing the gap* It's a bit bigger when I'm on my back, but it's still just a little bit. *looks up at the doctor with tears in eyes* I don't know, it just hurts and makes me feel uncomfortable.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I'm so sorry to see you're feeling uncomfortable and scared. I want to reassure you that we're going to do everything we can to help you feel better. 

Can you tell me more about when you see your mom or dad holding you or changing your diaper? Do you feel like it's the same thing that's causing you discomfort? 

*examines the patient's abdomen and the gap between the thighs, making a note*

text: RESULTS: Vital Signs: Temperature: 37.1°C (98.6°F), Blood Pressure: Normal for age, Heart Rate: 125 bpm (slightly elevated), Respiratory Rate: 32 breaths/min (slightly elevated); Abdominal Ultrasound: Dilated bowel segments with absence of gas in the rectum, suggesting a possible obstruction; Abdominal Examination: Abdomen is soft but distended, with crying intensifying on palpation especially in the left lower quadrant, a tympanitic sound noted in the left lower quadrant, and a visible gap between the thighs, approximately 1 cm in diameter; Stool Exam: Presence of blood in stool; Oral Examination: Mouth is closed, no signs of oral thrush or other issues; Anal Examination: Mild erythema and irritation in the anal area, possible signs of infection; Perineal Examination: Mild erythema and irritation in the anal area, possible signs of infection; Fecal Occult Blood Test: Positive for blood in stool; Perineal Examination: Mild erythema and irritation in the anal area, possible signs of infection; Stool Exam with detailed analysis: Presence of blood in stool, with possible signs of intestinal obstruction or other gastrointestinal issues.

speaker: Doctor
text:
It seems like you've had a thorough examination and test results. I'm going to take a moment to review everything and discuss the findings with your parents. 

Based on the test results, the abdominal ultrasound, and the examination findings, I'm concerned that you might have an intestinal obstruction. The presence of blood in your stool, a visible gap between the thighs, and the tympanitic sound in the left lower quadrant all suggest that there's something blocking the flow of stool through your intestines. 

Can you tell me more about your stool consistency and whether it's been changed at all since you started feeling uncomfortable? 

Also, I'd like to discuss the treatment options and a plan of care with your parents. We'll need to monitor your condition closely and possibly perform further tests to determine the underlying cause of the obstruction.

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really know... I just feel like I've been having trouble going to the bathroom and it hurts when I try. It doesn't feel like it's just gas or something, it feels like there's something stuck inside me.

speaker: Doctor
text:
I think I understand that you've had a thorough examination and test results. I'm going to take a closer look at your stool consistency and see if there's any other information that can help us determine the cause of the obstruction.

Can you tell me, have you noticed any changes in the consistency or color of your stool since you started feeling uncomfortable? For example, is it more watery or thicker, or has it changed color at all?

And I'd like to discuss the treatment options and a plan of care with your parents. We'll need to monitor your condition closely and possibly perform further tests to determine the underlying cause of the obstruction. 

Also, I'd like to ask one more question to confirm my findings. Can you point to the spot on your abdomen where it hurts the most, and can you describe the sensation to me? Is it more like a sharp pain or a dull ache?

speaker: Patient
text:
*looks up at the doctor with tears in eyes* It's... it's not really watery, it's more like... it's all clumpy. *sniffles* And it's red. *points to the stool in the diaper* It's red and clumpy. *looks down, fidgeting slightly* 

*crosses legs again, trying to show the gap between the thighs* 

*tenses up slightly when the doctor presses on the abdomen* Ow... 

*points to the middle of the abdomen, near the belly button* It hurts the most right here. *tries to show the doctor the exact spot*

speaker: Doctor
text:
I think we've gathered enough information to make a diagnosis. I'm going to go ahead and make a diagnosis.

DIAGNOSIS READY: Intestinal obstruction due to intussusception.
